Development.question: When was the Royal Flying Corps formed?
When did the Navy Wing split to form the Royal Navy Air Service?
What two corps merged to form the Royal Air Force?
Development.answer: The Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Navy Air Service.

Development.question: When was the Royal Air Force founded?
Who was the Chief of Air Staff upon the formation of the RAF?
What is the motto of the RAF?
Development.answer: 'Per Ardua Ad Astra' ('Through Struggles to the Stars').

Development.question: What was the role of the RAF and previous forces during WWI?
Development.answer: Reconnaissance and bombing with the emergence of fighters.

Development.question: How was the RAF organised before WWII?
Development.answer: They had 4 commands (formations): Fighter, Bomber, Coastal and Training.

Development.question: What was the role of the RAF during WWII?
Development.answer: Air power was incredibly important during WWII. The RAF carried out multiple bombing raids on Germany and beat the Luftwaffe in the Battle of Britain, arguably the biggest ever battle for the RAF.

Development.question: What was the role of the RAF during the Falklands War (1982)?
Development.answer:
- 1982 saw the RAF back in operation after little use in peace-time.
- Hercules and VC10 were used to transport people and equipment.
- Fighters were placed at the Ascension Islands.
- A Sea King and Chinook were used for sea rescues.
- A Victor K.2 were used for air to air refuelling.
- The Vulcan B.2 was supposed to be retired but their service was extended for the war.

Organisation.question: Who holds supreme responsibility of the RAF and other armed forces?
Organisation.answer: The Prime Minister and the Cabinet, via the Defence Council (led by the Secretary of State for Defence).

Organisation.question: Who is the RAF controlled by (under the Defence Council)?
Organisation.answer: A board of senior officers called the Air Force Board - each of these head a specialist branch of the RAF.

Organisation.question: What are the 2 RAF Commands?
Organisation.answer: Strike Command and Personnel and Training Command.

Organisation.question: What is an RAF Station?
Organisation.answer: A station consisting of around 5000 people that fulfils a certain role (such as Search and Rescue Training or holding a fleet of specialised aircraft).

Organisation.question: What is a unit?
Organisation.answer: A part of the RAF designated to a particular function.

Organisation.question: What is the smallest basic operational unit?
Organisation.answer: A squadron (roughly 120 people) - this may be divided into flights (roughly 30 people).

Organisation.question: What is the job of RAF Strike Command?
Organisation.answer: They control all the RAF offensive and defensive operations at home and overseas.

Organisation.question: What is the job of RAF Personnel and Training Command?
Organisation.answer: They control all aspects of recruitment, training, career management, welfare, pensions, etc. for RAF regular and reserve forces world-wide. They are responsible for over 500 training aircraft.

Organisation.question: What is a non-commissioned officer (NCO)?
Organisation.answer: A military officer who has not earned a commission - they usually obtain their position by promotion through the enlisted ranks.

Organisation.question: What is a commissioned officer?
Organisation.answer: A military officer who has earned a commission - they usually obtain their position by passing a competitive examination. In comparison to NCOs, they earn more money and have more legal responsibilities.

Organisation.question: What are the NCO ranks?
Organisation.answer: Lance Corporal (LCpl), Corporal (Cpl), Sergeant (Sgt), Flight Sergeant (Flt Sgt), (Cadet) Warrant Officer (CWO).

Organisation.question: What are the commissioned officer ranks?
Organisation.answer: Officer Cadet, Pilot Officer, Flying Officer, Flight Lieutenant (pronounced 'leftenant'), Squadron Leader, Wing Commander, Group Captain, Air Commodore, Air Vice-Marshal, Air Marshal, Air Chief Marshal, Marshal of the RAF.

Development.question: When was the Combined Cadet Force (CCF) officially established?
What was the initial strength of the RAF section of the CCF?
Who was the 'father' of the air cadet movement?
What is the Combined Cadet Force (CCF)?
Development.answer: A voluntary youth organisation in schools and colleges, sponsored by the Ministry of Defence. They may comprise of up to three sections: the Royal Navy (RN), Royal Army and the Royal Air Force (RAF).

Development.question: What are the aims of the CCF?
Development.answer:
- To promote the qualities of responsibilities, self-reliance, resourcefulness, endurance and perseverance.
- To provide the opportunity for young people to exercise responsibility and leadership and see how they can be developed.
- Develop a basic understanding of the armed forces.
- Encourage those who have an interest in the armed forces.

Organisation.question: Who administrates the RAF sections of the CCF?
Organisation.answer: The Headquarters Air Cadets (HQAC) at RAF College Cranwell.

Organisation.question: Who heads the Air Cadet Organisation?
Organisation.answer: A serving RAF Air Commodore, their formal title is the Commandant Air Cadets (Comdt AC).

Organisation.question: How is the relationship between the RAF and the CCF maintained?
Organisation.answer: Cadets attend the annual Easter and summer camps at RAF stations. They provide opportunities to see the daily life of an active station as well as having the opportunity to fly.

Organisation.question: What is the purpose of Year 9 training?
Organisation.answer: To provide an introduction to the RAF and the CCF.

Organisation.question: What is the purpose of Year 10 training?
Organisation.answer: To provide a more in-depth look at specialist ideas such as how to handrail a hill.

Organisation.question: What is the purpose of Year 11 training?
Organisation.answer: To provide a very detailed look at challenging elements of flying (such as the 1 in 60 rule) and how to teach lessons.

Airfields.question: What is an airfield?
Airfields.answer: An area (including any buildings and support installations) used for the accommodation, take-off and landing of aircraft.

Airfields.question: What is an airport?
Airfields.answer: An airfield with additional facilities for freight and passengers (for example customs, money-changing, immigration, baggage areas and restaurants).

Airfields.question: What is an aircraft manoeuvring area?
Airfields.answer: Parts an airfield which has been specially prepared for the movement of aircraft on the ground (for example runways, taxiways, aircraft servicing platforms, operational readiness platforms and dispersal hard standings).

Airfields.question: What is an Operational Readiness Platform (ORP)?
Airfields.answer: Specially-prepared areas (associated with fighter or strike airfields) built alongside the end of a runway. They are used for parking aircraft, either for rapid take-off with minimal warning (“scramble”) or for final flight preparation.

Airfields.question: What is an Aircraft Servicing Platform (ASP)?
Airfields.answer: Large paved areas for the servicing and turn-round of aircraft. They also facilitate the speedy handling of passengers and freight.

Airfields.question: What is a taxiway?
Airfields.answer: Paved roads that connect all the various parts of the aircraft manoeuvring area (e.g. Dispersal to runway, ORP to runway etc) and enable aircraft to move about easily. Minimum of 15m and are marked are in yellow.

Airfields.question: What does a windsock do?
Airfields.answer: It provides a quick and easy way of indicating wind direction. The main windsock (the one least subject to local effects) has a white ring round its base.

Airfields.question: What is an airfield identification beacon?
Airfields.answer: An open space on the airfield that flashes the airfield identification letters in Morse code using a high-intensity red light.

Airfields.question: What is a control tower?
Airfields.answer: A tall windowed structure located on the airfield grounds used to control the immediate airfield environment through visual obvservation. Surveillance displays as well as radar systems are used here for air monitoring assistance.

Airfields.question: What is an arrester gear?
Airfields.answer: A system that uses a strong hook to engage a cable in the aircraft which triggers cable braking, bringing the aircraft to a stop in a very short distance - this is especially useful for aircraft carriers.

Airfields.question: What is a sterile area?
Airfields.answer: An area used for security assessment, this is where passenger access to boarding aircraft is monitored and enabled/prevented.

Airfields.question: What is a terminal building?
Airfields.answer: An area where passengers transfer between ground transportation and the facilities that allow them to board and disembark from an aircraft.

Airfields.question: What is a runway?
Airfields.answer: A defined rectangular area on a land aerodrome, prepared for the landing and takeoff of aircraft.

Airfields.question: What coloured markings are used for the runway?
What is the typical size of a main instrument runway?
Airfields.answer: 45 metres wide and greater than 1800 metres long.

Airfields.question: What do the numbers on the runway mean?
Airfields.answer: They are the magnetic headings of the runway direction, to the nearest 10 degrees.

Airfields.question: What does the runway threshold look like?
Airfields.answer: Longitudinal white stripes pained symmetrically about the runway centre-line.

The Tutor and Air Experience Flying.question: How many Air Experience Flight (AEF) units are there across the country?
What is the purpose of Air Experience Flights?
The Tutor and Air Experience Flying.answer: To provide cadets with experience flying.

The Tutor and Air Experience Flying.question: What aircraft is used for Air Experience Flights?
The Tutor and Air Experience Flying.answer: The Grob Tutor, a small single-engine, low-winged monoplane.

The Tutor and Air Experience Flying.question: What engine is in the Grob Tutor?
What is the Grob Tutor made out of?
The Tutor and Air Experience Flying.answer: Modern composite materials such as carbon reinforced plastic.

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What radios are in an aircraft?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: There are two radios, one using the Ultra High Frequency (UHF) band and for air-to-air communication and the other using the Very High Frequency (VHF) band for air-to-ground communication.

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What is the attitude indicator (AI)?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: The AI is a gyroscopic instrument that indicates the attitude of the aircraft (position of the nose, if the plane is banked, etc.).

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What is the airspeed indicator (ASI)?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: The ASI tells the pilot the speed the aircraft is travelling through the air (in knots).

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What is the altimeter?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: The altimeter indicates the aircraft's height above the preset datum.

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What is the rate of climb and decent indicator (RCDI) (also known as the vertical speed indicator (VSI))?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: This instrument shows the pilot the rate at which the aircraft is climbing or descending.

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What is the turn and slip indicator?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: This instrument tells the pilot the rate at which the aircraft is turning, the direction of the turn and whether the aircraft is skidding or slipping.

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What is the horizontal situation indicator (HSI)?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: This instrument is a gyroscopic instrument that (after being synchronised with the compass) tells the pilot the heading of the aircraft.

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What is the control column (or stick)?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: The control column controls the ailerons and elevators to change the aircraft's pitch and roll. The pitch is inverted (pushing the stick down increases the pitch and vice versa).

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What are the rudder pedals?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: The rudder pedals controls the rudder to change the aircraft's yaw. Rudders are used a lot in aerobatics but in normal flights, they are used to maintain balanced flights and land in crosswinds.

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What is the RPM gauge?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: The RPM gauge shows the speed at which the engine is rotating in revolutions per minute (RPM). They typically use a scale of 1:100 (e.g. a reading of 20 means 2000 RPM).

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What is the manifold pressure gauge?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: This instrument indicates how much power is being supplied by the engine. It is calibrated in inches of mercury.

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What are the temperature and pressure gauges?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: These are two small instruments that show various temperatures (in degrees Celsius) and the pressures (in pounds per square inch) within the engine.

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What are flaps?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: Flaps are used on approach and takeoff as they give a lower approach speed and a more nose-down attitude. Thry are positioned at the rear of each wing.

Parts of an Aircraft.question: What is the elevator trimmer?
Parts of an Aircraft.answer: The elevator trimmer allows the pilot to make fine adjustments to the elevator so the aircraft can be flown at selected pitch attitudes without pressure on the stick.

What is a Map?.question: What is a map?
What is a Map?.answer: A diagrammatic representation of an area of land or sea that shows physical features, citites, roads, etc.

What is a Map?.question: What is longitude?
What is a Map?.answer: A geographic coordinate that specifies the east-west position of a point on the Earth's surface. They are circular and numbered, their starting point is at Greenwich, England (this is known as the prime meridian).

What is a Map?.question: What is latitude?
What is a Map?.answer: The angular distance of a place north or south of the equator of the Earth or another celestial object.

What is a Map?.question: What is the Ordnance Survey?
What is a Map?.answer: A governmental department based in Southmapton that produces maps for the UK.

Map Language.question: What is true north?
Map Language.answer: The geographic north pole of the Earth.

Map Language.question: What is grid north?
Map Language.answer: The direction of north on a map.

Map Language.question: What is magnetic north?
Map Language.answer: The direction of north as indicated by a compass.

Map Language.question: What is a scale?
Map Language.answer: A ratio of a distance on the map to the corresponding distance on the ground.

Map Language.question: What is a contour line?
Map Language.answer: A line on a map that connects points of equal elevation.

Map Language.question: What are gridlines?
Map Language.answer: A series of numbered horizontal and vertical lines that divide a map into squares, forming a grid. They are used by grid references to pinpoint features on a map.

Map Language.question: What is a grid reference?
Map Language.answer: A way of pinpointing a location on a map using a combination of letters and numbers.

Map Language.question: What is a relief?
Map Language.answer: The rise and fall of the ground (e.g. hills and valleys).

Map Language.question: What is a ridge (also known as a saddle)?
Map Language.answer: A long, narrow stretch of elevated ground. A col is known as the lower part of the ridge between the summits when a ridge has a peak at each end.

Map Language.question: What is a spur?
Map Language.answer: A piece of high ground that juts from a range of hills into lower ground.

Map Language.question: What is a re-entrant?
Map Language.answer: A narrow valley, closed at one end, that separates two spurs.

Map Language.question: What is an escarpment?
Map Language.answer: A landform with sides sloping in opposite directions, consisting of a steep scarp slope and a gentler dip or back slope.

Map Language.question: What is a gradient?
Map Language.answer: The angle or degree of a slope. it is expressed as a ratio.
